ID111Caledonian MercuryEdinburghScotlandUnited Kingdom18140319informThe following letter received in town
column2: gives a description of the wanton and barbarous conduct of the American army
column3: in destroying a settlement of the Moravian missionaries
column4: in their late irruption into province:– Yesterday I received a very afflicting account from North America
column5: by a letter from New York
column7: concerning a report of the total destruction of our settlement
column9: by the American army under General Harrison. It was the consequence of the invasion of that province
column10: after the capture of the little fleet on Lake Erie
column11: and the defeat of the s[?]al British force under the [?] of occupying the Chapel and some other houses for our sick British soldiers
column12: and considering the danger the Christian Indians were in from the malice of the Americans
column14: that the Missionaries and the Indian Congregation should retreat farther into the country. When the Americans were successful in the latter
column15: it became necessary to take steps of effect it. The British behaved very kindly to the brethren
column16: and offered to purchase the houses and cottages
column17: but their defeat prevented it. On entering the place
column18: the Americans first pretended to be friendly
column19: and sorry that the Indians had fled
column20: who had gone with Mr and Mrs Denke (one of the Missionaries) up the river. Mr and Mrs Schnall
column23: remained. During the first night the Americans already changed their tone
column24: or rather showed their real character. They began to abuse the Missionaries with curses
column26: plundering the houses ; and General Harrison
column28: would grant no redress. They took every thing that was??? away ; and
column29: under a pretence that King's stores and English goods were lodged in the houses
column31: and every trunk and chest belonging to individuals. Commodore Perry
column32: who had defeated the Mosquito fleet on the lake
column34: and behaved rather better than the rest
column35: advicing the Missionaries to get away as fast as they could. They did so with difficulty
column36: and shortly after the Americans set the place on fire
column38: even every outhouse[?]. The poor Missionaries had a very tedious journey
column40: a settlement of the Brethren in Pennsylvania
column41: December 11. Whither the Christian Indians have fled is not known ; they had proposed to go to the Grand River
column42: about 100 miles off. war;United States--Relations--Great Britain;Great Britain--Relations--United States;Native Americans

column3: appears in the Sidney Gazette of 14th May
column4: stating that Peter Mills Acting Deputy Surveyor of Lands at Port Dalrymple
column7: Acting Deputy Commissary of Stores and provisions at the said settlement
column9: and fled to the woods ; that their object was to live by rapine and violence ; to effect which they had armed themselves
column10: and taken the command of a gang of 26 desperadoes
column11: with whose aid they had committed numerous robberies–entering the lands of settlers
column13: and plundering their houses. The proclamation declares that those who shall return to their houses and occupations before 1st December next
column14: shall be pardoned and saved harmless from all offences
column15: except the crime of wilful murder ; and denounces those who shall disregard this offer
column18: Jan. 4. The Argo has arrived with a most extensive supply of tea
column23: and young hyson 50 ; in all 617 chests. The consequences has been a reduction in the price of souching from 30s to 5s per lb currency. Shortly prior to the Argo's departure from the Island of Mauritius
column28: was captured by his Majesty's sloop Harpy
column29: Captain Allen. In consequences of the oppressive conduct of several masters of colonial and British ships
column30: and of their crews towards the natives of New Zealand
column32: and of the other islands in the South Pacific Ocean
column33: which have led to the destruction of several vessels
column36: and disturbed all trade and intercourse with those islands
column37: both by British shipping and that ofthe allied powers–his Excellency has forbidden any vessel to clear out from any place in New South Wales
column38: without a bond given by the master or owner to the naval officer for the time being at the port
column40: binding him and his crew not to commit any act of hostility
column41: or to be guilty of any trespass
column42: or forment any animosities between the natives
column43: or take any part in any war that may prevail ; nor forcibly carry away any male or female inhabitants of the islands under penalty of forfeiting the sum specified in the bond. A small party
column44: who a short time ago undertook[?] a land passage in a direction towards Broken Bay
column45: for the purpose of ascertaining the nature and fertility of the country
column46: have discovered an excellent grazing track of 8000acres. In consequence of which one gentlemen
column48: has already sent thither an extensive herd of cattle
column49: and this example is likely to be followed by others. Thomas West
column50: who came to this colony a convict for life
column53: has received from his Excellency a conditional pardon
column54: in consideration of his general good conduct and character for sobriety and industry
column55: and also in consideration of his having lately erected a water mill for the grinding of grain at Barcorn Glen
column57: being the first water mill ever erected in the vicinty of this town. Sydney
column59: May 21. The good understanding between the natives and our settlers
column60: which had been maintained for the last six years
column61: has given place to frequent outrages attended with fatal consequences. On Saturday
column62: a body of 60 natives commenced plundering the fields of a settler
column63: when three privates of the veteran battalion fired upon them and killed a boy. The narushed upon them before they could load again
column66: and compelled the other two to fly. They then plundered the ground of Messrs Milehouse and Butcher. Next day a party of 14 soldiers falling in with them
column67: shot a woman and two children–the savages attacked William Baker
column69: killed the man and two women
column72: Feb. 12. On Monday last arrived the ship General Hewett
column75: having a detachment of the 46th regiment
column76: commanded by Major Oglivie ; and yesterday arrived the Windham
column79: having on board the head-quarters of the 46th regiment
column83: and is accompanied by Mrs Molle and family ; also Lieutenant Walters
column85: agent for transports– Of the 300 convicts which the General Hewett received on board
column86: 35 died on the passage. settlement description;crime;colonial government;international trade;Maori;Pacific Islanders;transportation

column1: ID113Caledonian MercuryEdinburghScotlandUnited Kingdom18140912inform[Extracts of Letters from Quebec and Montreal.] Quebec
column2: July 15. The commercial world is flourishing here
column5: we are sadly in the back ground. The old defensive system is still adhered to
column9: we shall do little good till we have another commander in chief. There is now a great body of regular troops in this country
column10: and a handful of brave fellows have recently been almost sacrificed par la petite guerre at Chippawa
column14: 000 regulars doing nothing. Some of the officers of the regiments lately arrived from France do not conceal their sentiments– On inspecting one of the regiments the other day
column17: to make some remarks on the cut of the men's clothes
column18: when the Colonel commanding stepped forward and told him plainly
column19: that such systems were now completely exploded–that he had had the honour of serving very lately under a much more celebrated General that it was probable he would ever serve under again–that his men had been accustomed to fight
column20: not to dance ; and if such was the plan he was called on to follow
column21: he should certainly retire from the service. Such language you may suppose was not very pleasing to our Governor ; but I am happy to find that we now have military men amongst us
column22: who are not afraid to speak out ; as it appears the numberless representations of civilians are not much attended to. Montreal
column23: July 14. I consider this country now as perfectly secure against any attempts that the Americans may make
column24: not withstanding the system of our chief does not seem to be changed. He has received a great many more troops this year than he had any idea of
column25: and does not seem pleased at having so large a force unhis command
column26: as the country will now look to him for some offensive operation against the enemy. He has done nothing the whole summer but parade about 6000 men at Chambly
column27: where he makes them march past him twice a-week
column29: instead of employing them where they ought to be. You will have heard of an American army of about 6000
column31: having crossed the river at Fort Erie
column34: gallantly assailed them but was overpowered by numbers
column35: and sustained considerable loss. I inclose a general order published yesterday about this unfortunate business
column36: whereby you will find that our loss has been great. Upon this frontier the Americans have hardly any force
column37: and it appears very singular indeed
column38: that so great a body of men
column39: as are now on the other side of the river
column40: from Sorel to Isle Aux Noix
column43: should be left for the purpose of parade
column44: when they are so much wanted in the upper province. I sincerely hope that some investigation will take place into this business
column45: as it is really disgraceful to think that such an enemy should be able to make an attack upon us with impunity. international trade;military;war;United States--Relations--Great Britain;Great Britain--Relations--United States

column4: landed and at tacked Fort Michillimackinac
column6: on the 4th August. They were repulsed by the British garrison. The American fort la Prairie du Chiens has been taken by the British. This place was considered as of great importance to the enemy. Major General Conran
column8: has had the misfortune to break his leg
column9: by a fall from his horse. This officer had just arrived to join the army on the Niagara frontier
column10: when he met with this accident. On the 31st August
column11: the British troops broke their encampment at Odell Town
column13: and proceeded immediately to take possession of the position which the American army had just abandoned at the village of Champlain. This army was commanded by General Izard
column14: and are said to have proceeded partly to Plattsburgh
column16: on Lake Ontario. The British troops now at Champlain are commanded by Major Gene rals Brisbane
column24: &c. &c. The 79th[?] or [?] Glasgow Lowland regiment are now quartered at Cornwall
column25: in Upper Canada. The 4th[?] battalion of the 1st
column36: and 41st flank[?] companies are with the army under Lieutenant General Drummon
column38: Upper Canada. The 37th and 57th regiments are at Montreal. On the 15th of August
column39: the British troops under Lieutenant General Drummond assaulted Fort Erie. The attack was made in three columns
column40: under Colonel Scott of the 103d regiment
column42: and Lieutenant Colonel Fischer of de Watteville's. The two former were directed to scale the fort
column43: and the latter to get possession of a small hill
column46: and being situated only about eight hundred yards from Fort Erie
column47: was of consequence to us. This latter column failed in their object ; but the two columns destined for the fort carried the same in a most gallant manner
column48: and obliged the enemy to retire into two stone block-houses inside the fort
column49: when their own guns were turned against them. At this time a most unfortunate explosion took place
column50: which blew up the magazine and battery
column51: and with them a number of our brave soldiers ; and the consternation caused by this was so great
column52: and we were obliged to abandon our conquest
column53: and retreat to our original position
column54: with great loss of both officers and men. The large ship-building by the British at Kingston
column55: on Lake Ontario is to be launched the second week in September– also will carry about 100 guns. The battalion of royal marines
column57: and which has been stationed lately at Isle au Noix
column59: have been broken up and distributed among the fleets on the Lakes. The Staff of the battalion proceed immediately to Halifax from Quebec
column60: in the Ceylong armed-en [?] ship. The Junon frigate
column62: has arrived from Halifax at Quebec
column63: with money for Government. The crew of this vessel is to be employed on the Lakes. A brig
column69: are hourly expected. It is said that there are on board the ships of the latter about 4000 troops
column70: chiefly detachments and reinforcements for the regimentsin Canada. Captain Dowale
column72: now commands the fleet on Lake Champlain. war;United States--Relations--Great Britain;Great Britain--Relations--United States;military;navy

column2: Sept. 3. The army from this province has entered the United States by the Champlain frontier. On the 1st inst. the advance was at Chazy. Quebec
column3: Sept. 8. From the north-western frontier of Upper Canada
column5: who arrived here on Thursday last
column6: have brought dispatches from Lieutenant Colonel M'Donal
column8: written since the repulse of the American forces sent there to recapture it. The following are the particulars of that expedition :– On the forenoon of the 5th of August
column11: at the back of the island (Dowsman's farm). There is a considerable space of ground cleared
column14: at anchor close to the beach
column16: by a constant fire of grape
column17: &c. and which by the situation of the ground
column18: passed directly over the men's heads
column19: as they formed and advanced towards the woods. Lieutenant-Colonel M'Doual[?] formed his small garrison (150 at most) at the extremity of the woods
column20: and the Indians were stationed on each flank
column21: to keep the enemy from outflanking the troops. By a false account of the enemy's intention to land on another part of the island
column22: a certain number of Indians were sent to watch their motions ; but more Indians absenting themselves
column23: exposed one flank of Lieutenant-Colonnel M'Doual's party entirely ; and an apprehension was entertained that the enemy would outflank and cut off the garrison from the forts ; it was therefore deemed expedient to fall back between the two forts
column24: and there await the advance of the enemy. A party of between 40 and 50 Indians
column26: and ignorant of the movements in the centre and right flank
column30: and encouraging each other by whoops and yells
column31: totally broke the little order still observed by the enemy
column33: and were all out of reach before Lieutenant-Colonel M'Doual was apprised of their retreat. Thus was a body of at least from six to nine hundred men defeated and put to instant flight by 40 or 50 Indians
column34: with a loss of 17 men and a Major (Holmes) killed and found on the spot!–The Indians lost but one man. Previous to and combined with this
column35: the measures taken by the enemy were these: On the [?] of July
column36: a detachment of the expedition sent against Michillimackinac by the enemy
column38: where they met with no resistance
column39: there being neither troops nor Indians
column40: and every person occupied about their usual concerns ; such as bay making
column41: fishing &c. Major Holmes commanded the party
column42: who gave up to indiscriminate plunder
column43: and destroyed the whole of the property belonging to the North West Company ; burning their houses
column47: and taking off their engagees prisoners ; tearing down the fences
column50: &c. Many wanton acts of cruelty might be detailed. Let two suffice for the present. Mr Johnstone's property was plundered
column51: even his furniture ; the very clothing of his wife and children was seized upon by these ruthless plunderers
column52: and carried away. Major Holmes sent to the south side of the strait for Mr Johnstone's son George
column54: after threatening and reviling him with the most oppobrious language
column55: flourished his sword over his head
column56: and said he had a great mind to cut his head off
column58: When they were in the act of burning the houses and stores
column59: Mr G. Johnstone was ordered to stand in a certain spot
column60: under pain of being shot ; but had he remained
column61: sufforation[?] must have been his fate
column62: being so near the buildings in flames : he therefore risked being shot
column64: and thereby effected a timely escape. Another instance of more than savage cruelty was exercised on a poor horse
column65: which they made us of all day in carting their plunder
column67: whilst still tackled to the cart
column68: tied him to the end of the dwelling-house then in flames
column69: and amused themselves in looking at the poor animal making vain efforts to get loose ; but there he was burnt
column70: and his bones seen there by the writer of this. war;United States--Relations--Great Britain;Great Britain--Relations--United States;Native Americans

column2: Oct. 29 The express from Upper Canada
column4: confirmed the highly satisfactory reports of the preceding day
column5: that the enemy had precipitately retreated on the 19th instant
column7: after destroying a quantity of provisions and heavy baggage ; and that
column9: they had passed over to Buffaloe a great part of their force
column10: and were blowing up the works at Fort Erie. Further accounts from Kingston have been received this morning to the 26th instant
column11: when the official report of the enemy's retreat from Fort Erie
column12: after the destruction of the works
column14: but there was no doubt of the fact. Major-Genera de Watteville commanded the corps pressing on the enemy ; the master of a mail which arrived at Kingston on the 25th
column15: in twenty-four hours from Fort George
column17: and reports that several hundred prisoners were taken
column18: before the Americans effected their escape across the river. On the 18th the British came up with his rear guard
column19: and in a sharp action thirty of the Americans were left on the field wihtout a casualty happening on our side. This was at Chippawa Creek.– The enemy then fled with the utmost precipitation to Fort Erie
column20: and began the destruction of his fortifications. A military courier from Kingston arrived this morning
column21: brings no additional news of importance.– Sir James Yeo had returned to Kingston with the sick of the army of Niagara on board. We again sailed for the head of the Lake. A private letter from Niagara of the 10th instant
column22: says that a severe action took place the day before near Chippawa ; our loss is stated at 10 killed and wounded. That of the enemy is supposed to be very considerable ; a field piece made to bear upon one of his columns did great execution. Another letter denies any loss in killed but makes the wounded 25 or 30. Montreal
column23: Nov. 5. From Upper Canada we have received nothing of importance. The report of the whole American armies have crossed the Niagara was a mistake as the last accounts from that quarter mention that General Brown was still in possession of Fort Erie. Quebec
column24: Nov. 3. We are in expectation of some further details of the operations on the Niagara frontier by this day's Montreal post ; but they had no arrived at one o'clock. The evacuation by the enemy of our territory on that frontier is a striking illustration of the importance of the command of the lake. The enemy did cross over to our side till the moment his fleet was ready to assume the superiority. The re-appearance of our fleet effected what could not be done by the expence of so much blood and treasure. (From the Quebec Gazette) The American Government has published the pa pers relating to the late negotations at Ghent. We confess that we have seen these papers with feelings of some satisfaction and much regret ; satisfaction that we can now say that the honour of the British Government is pledged to do something for British interests in North American
column25: and regret that that something is so little. The Indians are to be made independent of both nations. This is perfectly just
column27: under certain cirumstances greatly add to the security of these provinces. The Lakes are to be exclusively British. On these subjects we must be permitted to ask how long they would be permitted to remain so
column28: how long the Indians would retain their independence in the event of another war
column29: if the communication with them should be in the power of the enemy ? The sole communication for military purposes
column30: with the Indians and the Lakes
column31: is by the river St Lawrence
column33: and from Niagara to Fort Erie ; and the Americans are to be permitted to remain in possession of one of its banks ! The enemy has hitherto been prevented from interrupting this communication by the thinness of the settlements of their side
column34: the consequent badness of the roads
column35: and difficulty of supplying a large force. The possession of th southern bank of the St Lawrence between Montreal and Kingson
column36: and the power of supplying themselves
column40: has been worth a large force to them
column41: during the whole of the war ; it has caused us to parcel our force to support the line of communication between Lake St Francis and Kingston
column42: and keep a great proportion of it to protect the base of that line in the vicinity of Montreal. The position of Canada
column45: is an extraordinary one ; so much so
column46: that intelligent military men have pronounced it incapable of defence much beyond Quebec. The miserable state of the enemy's preparations
column47: the superiority which we then had on the Lakes
column48: the good disposition of the inhabitants
column49: and the prudent conduct of the commander of the forces
column50: alone saved it. The waste of means in protecting and conveying supplies by a communication of five hundred miles
column51: adjoining the whole way to the enemy's frontie
column52: is conceivable only to those whom experience has made acquainted with the fact
column53: or who are habituated to reflection ; and whenever the communication of the Lakes becomes interrupted
column54: the supply of any force further advanced on the line becomes utterly impracticable. The enemy derives his supplies either by the Lakes
column55: upon which an army can effect nothing
column57: a long way in his rear
column60: and a militia more effective than the best troops in such a country
column61: always ready for the protection of their property and their houses– Under such circumstances
column62: the weakness of an army beyond a certain point is to be counted by its numbers. We scruple not to say
column64: whenever that part of the State of New York extending to the St Lawrence
column65: between Lake Ontario and Lake Champlain
column67: the whole of Upper Canada must fall to the United States
column68: the Lower Canada will not be defensible but at an expence of means far beyond its value. We had much rather see the Americans confirmed in the possession of Sackett's Harbour
column71: than in the possession of the tract of country just mentioned. Great Britain will always have the means of establishing a superiority on the Lakes
column72: whenever she chuses to exert them
column73: but she never will be able to drive the Americans out of that frontier
column75: supported as they will be by the immense population of the back parts of the State of New York and adjoining States. From the United States Papers Urbanna
column76: Sept. 25. An express has arrived from Detroit
column79: in which Governor Cass says– A state of things has arrived
column81: with the force at your disposal
column82: is essential to the security and preservation of the country. The Indians have recommenced hostilities on every side of us ; they are murdering the people
column83: and breaking up the settlements. There is now a large force of them in the immediate vicinity of this place
column84: most probably within a mile of it
column85: with the avowed purpose of attacking the town. We have no force adequate to the defence of the country
column86: and none of description proper for the pursuit of the Indians– My opinion is
column87: that you should hasten on with the mounted men with all possible expedition. The express came by water
column88: the land communiation being entirely cut off. Albany
column89: Oct. 25. The Legislature of this State adjourned yesterday
column90: after a session of four weeks. The principal laws passed are: An act to authorise the raising of troops for the defence of this State. An act to encourage privateering. An act to authorise the raising of a corps of sea fencibles. An act to provide for the repayment of certain sums of money advanced by the Corporation of the city of New York
column91: for the defence of the State
column92: and for other purposes. An act to prevent the apprehension of British deserters. An act to authorise the raising of two regiments of men of colour. An act authorising additional pay to be made to the volunteers
column93: and for paying the militia called into service by the State authority. An act to aid in the apprehension of deserters from the army and navy of the United States. The first act authorises the Governor to call into actual service 12
column95: for the term of two years
column96: provided the Government of the United States shall have declared their intention to pay
column97: clothe and subsist them at their expence. The privateer bill authorises associations to incorporate themselves for the purpose of fitting out privateers. The following resolution
column99: passed both Houses of our Legislature unanimously on Saturday:– Resolved unanimously–That the House of Assembly of the State of New York view
column100: with mingled emotions of surprise and indignation
column101: the extravagant and disgraceful terms proposed by the British Commissioners at Ghent–that
column102: however ardently they may desire the restoration of peace to their country
column103: they can never consent to receive it at the sacrifice of national honour and dignity–that they therefore strongly recommend to the National Legislature the adoption of the vigorous and efficacious measures in the prosecution of the war
column104: as the best means of the bringing the contest to an honourable termination
column105: and of transmitting unimpaired to their posterity their rights
column107: and independence. The following is a private letter which was brought by the Liffey : Montreal
column108: Nov. 5. 1814. Sir George Prevost reached Kingston on the 10th October
column109: where his presence has been of the utmost importance. Chauncey resigned his blockade of that place on the 8th
column110: and retired with his squadron to Sackett's Harbour. Our fleet which was ready for the Lake in a few days after Sir George's arrival
column113: and a supply of provisions and stores for the right division
column114: and arrived off Fort George on the evening of the 18th. Having landed this reinforce ment
column115: Sir James returned to Kingston on the 24th. The enemy at Fort Erie having been joined by General Izard's army
column116: making a force of 7 or 8000 men
column118: and attacked our positions upon the Chippawa on the 15th instant ; but having met with an opposition unexpected by them
column120: retired on the 16th and 17th to Black Creek
column121: from whence they advanced one of Izard's brigades
column124: with a view of our turning our right
column125: and attempted to cross the Chippawa
column126: about six miles from its mouth
column127: where they were met with by a corps of about 1000 troops
column129: who faced them most manfully ; they skirmished the whole day
column130: in which the Glengarries supported their high character
column134: and unable to bring up his artillery from the horrid state of the roads
column135: retired again to the main body at Black Creek. Our casualties on this occasion were triflin– those of the enemy were said to have been considerable
column136: though he refrained from exposing himself to our fire in the open ground. We had two field-pieces there
column137: and whenever the enemy showed a column out of the wood
column138: a well-directed discharge soon obliged them to return to their shelter. By this time our fleet being announced
column140: and they commenced a precipitate retreat to Fort Erie. They were purused on the 20th and 21st by our advance
column143: where he found them occupying the high ground
column144: which General Drummond had not left many weeks before
column145: and could push no further. At the date of the last accounts from General Drummond
column147: from which it will require a few columns of fresh troops to dislodge him
column148: but as they are now on their way to join the right dividion
column149: I trust I shall in a short time have the pleasure to acquaint you of the complete expulsion of the enemy from the Niagara frontier. It is said
column150: that for want of sufficient shelter
column151: a part of General Izard's force had crossed to Buffalo
column152: and that they had passed over some heavy artillery and stores
column153: leaving at the fort such a force as they conceived capable of defending it. Sir James brough down with him the skeleton of the 1st battalion of the King's regiment
column154: and the remains of the two flank companies of the 10th. He sailed again on the 1st inst. taking with him about 1200 men
column158: and detachments from the 6th and 82d regiments
column159: and a large supply of provisions and stores. The five hundred of the 9th regiment who marched to York would be crossed to Niagara in the brigs ; the 9th
column161: were to have been embarked in the fleet
column162: but Sir James could not take them. The Royals
column167: return to Kingston by this trip of the fleet
column168: which I fear was scarcely able to make another this season. The St Lawrence has proved a noble ship
column169: and one and all seem delighted with her. The frigate in frame arrived at Kingston
column170: where she has been laid down and lengthened to make her the size of the Prince Regent. The keel of a 74 is also laid down there. The Americans are said to have commenced upon two more ships of the class of the Superior. Letters from Michilimacinack to the 19th October state
column171: that the capture of the two schooners will be attended with the most important benefits in the security of that post
column172: and the territory dependent upon it. Captain Rocheblave
column173: with the detachment of the 81st under Capt. Wardrop
column176: without any casualty among the troops ; and Mr M'Kenzie
column178: would arrive about the 21st. The two schooners had made a trip to Nottawasage for provisions and supplies
column179: and would attempt another before the navigation closed. A reinforcement had been sent under Capt Bulgar to Praire du Chain. The arrangements necessary for reinforcing and supplying General Drummond's army being completed
column180: and the attack upon Sackett's Harbour being deemed impracticable this season
column181: Sir George returned last evening to this place ; his journey to Kingston has certainly had the effect of inducing General Brown
column182: with a considerable part of his force
column184: and has thus left General Izard so much weakened at Fort Erie
column185: that I have little doubt of the result of an attack upon him. I am sorry to see that the malice of a certain party here has been at work at your side of the water ; it has increased tenfold since the expression of the public sentiment in favour of his Excellency
column186: by the addresses which are now preparing
column187: and which I can assure you is the real and unsolicited voice of the people. I am happy to find that General Kempt is going to England
column188: as he will afford true information upon the state of the country
column189: and be able to exposethe falsehoods which have been circulated respecting recent events. war;United States--Relations--Great Britain;Great Britain--Relations--United States;Native Americans;military;privateering
